chapter.title: Post-Course Self-Assessment
chapter.content:
Return to the Pre-Course Self-Assessment (Motivation and Persistence Strategies Self-Assessment Chart [Word]) you did at the beginning of the course. In the “Post” column, enter a score to indicate the degree to which your understanding may have changed. You will use this information to plan your next steps.

 

 

Return to main course page.

chapter.title: Next Steps
chapter.content:
To plan your own next learning steps, select 3 of the following tasks you want to do next to help prepare you to implement what you have learned from this course in your own classroom:

  1. Review the pre-/post-assessment scores on your self-assessment, together with the notes you took in your Motivation and Persistence Strategies chart and your journal. Which principles stand out as areas you want to learn more about? If you took the Adult Education Teacher Competencies Self-Assessment, how did your results inform learning more about motivation and persistence strategies and evidence-based instruction?

  2. Visit the LINCS Learning Portal and take the online course on Principles of Learning for Instructional Design. The course follows a very similar format and complements Motivating Adult Learners to Persist, using the same research basis.

  3. Review the Course Resource List to identify additional readings and resources that may be helpful.

  4. Consider possibilities for observing yourself (through video) or other teachers as one way to continue developing. (For tips on videotaping your own and other classes, see the Harnessing Technology page.)

  5. Return to the discussions in the LINCS Communities of Practice to discover more about evidence-based instruction in the areas of your interests and responsibilities.

  6. Plan to take the course self-assessment again in several months to note changes in your practice, needs, and priorities.

  7. Visit the Teacher Effectiveness page on LINCS.

chapter.title: Course Resource List
chapter.content:
• Adult Education Teacher Induction Toolkit
    Website: http://lincs.ed.gov/programs/teachereffectiveness/toolkit
    Designed for adult educators, the Adult Education Teacher Induction Toolkit contains a wide variety of tools that support the use of evidence-based instruction by beginning teachers, mentors, and their instructional leaders. The Toolkit also provides instant access to background research and supplemental resources from the literature on teacher effectiveness.

  • Literacy Information and Communication System (LINCS)
    Website: http://lincs.ed.gov
    LINCS features a Learning Portal with additional online courses, an extensive curated collection of high-quality online resources, informed by research, for use by adult educators , and information about locating regional professional learning opportunities. The site also features several online communities of practice within which practitioners can exchange ideas with colleagues and subject matter experts.

  • New England Literacy Resource Center's Adult Learner Persistence
    Website: http://nelrc.org/persist/index.html
    This site features tools, models, strategies, and research on how to help adults persist in learning. The site shares the results of action research conducted by 18 programs as part of the New English Learner Persistence project; it also features additional resources from other programs and states.

  • Related Publications by National Academies Press
    Website: http://sites.nationalacademies.org/DBASSE/DBASSE_072426
    This site features three publications from the Improving Adult Literacy Instruction: Options for Practice and Research report; a report brief, a policy brief, and a research brief.  Also, the booklet Improving Adult  Literacy Instruction:  Developing Reading and Writing can be downloaded.  (The latter is also available through the LINCS Resource Collection).

  • Teaching Excellence in Adult Literacy (TEAL) Center Website
    Website: https://teal.ed.gov/resources
    This site features a glossary, a bibliography of works related to evidence-based instructional practices, publications supporting writing, and a wide range of practical fact sheets on related topics.

  • Teaching Channel
    Website: https://www.teachingchannel.org/videos?default=1
    The Teaching Channel website features K–12-oriented videos that are professionally produced. These include many related to English language arts and math, and so may be comparable to topics and skills addressed in ABE instruction. You need to create a free account to access these videos, but anyone may do so.
